speaker: Skyline
text: A moon rises above the city.  _ACT I  Scene 1 - KACL Frasier is finishing a segment._

speaker: Frasier
text: And we'll be right back after this short news break.

speaker: Gil
text: Frasier...I'm here to give you an advance tip.

speaker: Frasier
text: Really?

speaker: Roz
text: Hey, Gil.

speaker: Gil
text: Roz!  I'm about to review a divine new Italian trattoria I've discovered called "Bella, Bella."

speaker: Frasier
text: Ah-ha.

speaker: Gil
text: I'm alerting you now because once I review it, reservations will be impossible to come by.

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, thank you, Gil, it's always gratifying to be a few minutes ahead of a trend.

speaker: Gil
text: They make an osso bucco that's so divine I call it the "Veal Shank Redemption."

speaker: Kenny
text: Hey, guys.

speaker: Frasier
text: Hello, Kenny.

speaker: Kenny
text: Show's going great, Frasier, uh, only one thing missing, of course...

speaker: Frasier
text: I know, I know, a new theme song.  I'm sorry, I just haven't gotten around to it yet.

speaker: Kenny
text: Well, Mrs. Delafield's been hounding me on this.  She really thinks each show having a theme song will help hook the listeners.  Gil's got his.

speaker: Gil
text: My first choice was "Food, Glorious Food" from the show _Oliver!_

speaker: Frasier
text: Ooh, that's a perfect match.  Haute cuisine and a chorus of starving orphans.

speaker: Gil
text: But then, a composer friend of mine came up with this little ditty for me [_He sings:_] _Whether choosing a wine Or the best place to dine-- It's all a matter of taste (Yes, sir!) It's all a matter of taste!_

speaker: Kenny
text: Great, huh?

speaker: Gil
text: And the nicest thing is, he didn't take a penny for it!

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, at least he has a conscience.

speaker: Frasier
text: You know, Kenny, I'm sorry for procrastinating this thing. I-I tell you, I'll get one as soon as I possibly can.

speaker: Kenny
text: Well, you better come up with something here.  I'm sorry to be a hard-ass.  It's the part of my job I hate the most, but I need this thing on my desk by Monday...ish.

speaker: Frasier
text: You know, Roz - hearing Gil's little ditty puts me in mind that maybe we should just do - ah, an original song.

speaker: Roz
text: Well, my new boyfriend Leon is in a band.  He could write one for you.

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, actually, I was thinking of composing it myself.  I am not without musical ability, you know.

speaker: Roz
text: Could you at least hire Leon to accompany you?

speaker: Frasier
text: I take it he's desperate for work?

speaker: Roz
text: Hasn't had a gig in months.  Music is all he knows.  He's not good at anything else - except in bed.  It's what he does best.

speaker: Frasier
text: Yeah.  How long did it take you to find that out?

speaker: Roz
text: [_about the show_] Ten seconds, Frasier.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, longer than usual.  _She returns to her booth and he replaces his headphones.  FADE OUT  Scene 2 - Frasier's apartment He opens the door to Niles._

speaker: Niles
text: Frasier.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, Niles.  Oh, dear.  We had dinner plans tonight, didn't we?

speaker: Niles
text: Yes.  Don't tell me you're canceling.

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, I have to.  I have a little project this evening.

speaker: Niles
text: Oh.  Would this have anything to do with this new theme song you promised your listeners?

speaker: Frasier
text: As a matter of fact, it does.  I've got to have something by Monday, and I thought I'd take advantage of a nice quiet evening at home.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh.  Daphne - Daphne!  Would you please turn off that vacuum cleaner?

speaker: Daphne
text: It's not a vacuum cleaner.  It's the "Dirt Scourge 2000." A total cleansing system.

speaker: Martin
text: [_from his chair_] Is it new?

speaker: Daphne
text: Yeah.  I got it this afternoon.  You see, this water traps all of the dirt particles instead of recycling them back into the air.  I got all that [_indicating_] from Dr. Crane's pillow.

speaker: Martin
text: Ew.

speaker: Niles
text: I've been begging you to switch to a more abrasive loofah.

speaker: Daphne
text: Well, it would be the same for anyone.  Dead skin, dust mites... that's what we're all sleeping on, only we don't know it.

speaker: Martin
text: We do now.  Geez.

speaker: Daphne
text: This is the chance I've been waiting for. _She turns on the machine and begins to apply it to Martin's chair. The machine begins to audibly struggle, and the water in the tank immediately turns black and brackish.  Niles and Frasier watch with concern.  She has barely started when it suddenly shorts out, sparks flying in an electrical explosion.  When the smoke clears, Daphne walks back to the main part of the cleaner._

speaker: Frasier
text: Well.  Apparently the "Dirt Scourge 2000" is no match for the "Dirt Pile 1957."

speaker: Daphne
text: Well, this is going back.  On the commercial they clean all the mud off a hippopotamus.  [_She exits._]

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, at least now I can get down to work.  You know, Niles, I'm sorry again about dinner, but can I buy you a sherry?

speaker: Niles
text: Oh... thank you.  About this theme song of yours... why don't you just use a standard?

speaker: Frasier
text: Actually, I want to compose one myself.  I've always had an affinity for music, and I've often wondered what I might achieve if I just rolled up my sleeves and gave it a try.

speaker: Martin
text: [_re-entering_] Didn't you write some kind of musical back in prep school?

speaker: Frasier
text: Yes, I did, Dad.  Niles was in it.  You know, the whole school came out humming my opening anthem.

speaker: Niles
text: They went in humming it.  It was Beethoven's Ninth Symphony note for note.

speaker: Frasier
text: [_over Niles_] It was not.

speaker: Niles
text: It absolutely was.

speaker: Frasier
text: It was not at all.

speaker: Niles
text: [_singing to the tune of the "Ode to Joy" theme from the finale of Beethoven's Ninth:_] _We are valiant men of honor Wenching, brawling sons of..._

speaker: Frasier
text: All right, all right, well, I suppose I may have borrowed a Note or two as a launching pad.

speaker: Niles
text: [_moving to the third, contrasting phrase of the Beethoven theme_]

speaker: Frasier
text: All right, point taken.

speaker: Niles
text: _Over hill and..._

speaker: Frasier
text: Stop it!

speaker: Niles
text: I'm just teasing.  Actually, it was a wonderful show.  I was very proud to be acting in it.

speaker: Frasier
text: You know, Niles, you were wonderful in it as well.

speaker: Niles
text: Well, thank you, I thought so.

speaker: Frasier
text: Mm-hmm.

speaker: Niles
text: I often thought if I'd kept at it, I could have been a professional actor.

speaker: Frasier
text: Ah, you see, we all have a road not taken, some unfinished business worth exploring.

speaker: Martin
text: Yeah, I always wanted to be a toe dancer, but a bullet ended my dream.

speaker: Niles
text: Well, Frasier, if you need any help with this, I'm right here.

speaker: Frasier
text: Thank you, Niles.  You know, I'd rather handle the composing chores myself, but I could use a sounding board.

speaker: Niles
text: Fair enough, let's put our heads together.

speaker: Frasier
text: All right.

speaker: Niles
text: Figuratively speaking, of course.  I saw what came out of your pillow.  _They head back toward the piano.  FADE TO:_  **A BRIDGE TOO FAR**  _Scene 3 - Later that night Niles plunks out some notes on the piano.  Frasier is standing._

speaker: Niles
text: You know, I think this new bridge is the best thing you've written.

speaker: Frasier
text: Really?

speaker: Niles
text: Oh, absolutely.  _He sings to a jaunty tune, beginning with the notes he had plunked and accompanying himself:_

speaker: Niles
text: _Claustrophobia Nymphomania He will probe ya He'll explain t'ya_ It's brilliant.

speaker: Frasier
text: You know, it does have a Cole Porter-y, Stephen Sondheim-y flavor, doesn't it?

speaker: Niles
text: Oh, absolutely.  Sondheim-y would have killed to have written this.

speaker: Frasier
text: You know what?  I'm a little nervous.  It just may be a bit too conventional.  Perhaps instead of a regular bridge, I could substitute it with a dramatic monologue spoken against a musical background.

speaker: Niles
text: [_after a beat_] I like it.

speaker: Frasier
text: Of course, I would have to hire an actor.

speaker: Niles
text: Yes, I suppose you could squander a lot of money on some so- Called professional... someone who doesn't know a thing about psychiatry. [_reaching_] Who doesn't understand the whole Gestalt.

speaker: Frasier
text: Or maybe you could do it.

speaker: Niles
text: I think so.

speaker: Frasier
text: I will write you a speech that will challenge your entire histrionic range!  This is so exciting!  Let's play the chorus again.

speaker: Martin
text: Hey, hey, Fras!  I just got an idea for your little jingle. It came to me while I was brushing my teeth. [_He sings:_] _What's new?  I'm listenin' Feelin' blue?  I'm listenin'..._ Cause, you know, that's what you say on your show. _Feelin' sad, feelin' mad, feelin' glad, feelin' bad I'm listenin'!_

speaker: Daphne
text: [_who has been seated at the dining table_] Bravo!  That's wonderful.

speaker: Martin
text: Thanks, you know, it's catchy.  That's what counts in a jingle.  [_N.B. Of interest: John Mahoney appeared on the Cheers episode "Do Not Forsake Me, O My Postman" as Sy Flembeck, a hapless jingle composer._]

speaker: Frasier
text: [_politely_] Uh-huh, well, that's very, very nice, Dad, it's just that, well, you know, I did promise my listeners that I'd compose this myself.  It's no fair cheating.

speaker: Martin
text: Oh, well, it's not cheating, technically...

speaker: Frasier
text: [_cutting him off_] Very good, Dad, very good, but thank you, and off you go.

speaker: Martin
text: Okay, all right.

speaker: Niles
text: Hey, um, Frasier, are you sure you want to modulate here? That may just complicate things.

speaker: Frasier
text: Perhaps.  You know, I'm just trying to make it interesting. To my ear, there's still something lacking, some tiny ingredient that's missing.  I'm not sure what.  _Scene 4 - DISSOLVE to a rehearsal hall, where a full orchestra is tuning their instruments.  Frasier stands on the conductor's podium._

speaker: Frasier
text: [_tapping his baton_] All right, everyone.  Let's try this again.  We still have a few minutes before the choir gets here.  _He raises his baton and prepares to cue the opening.  FADE OUT  END OF ACT I  ACT II  Scene 5 - The rehearsal hall The choir has arrived._

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, finally, the choir has deigned to join us.

speaker: Director
text: Sorry, our bus broke down.  We had to walk two miles to get here.

speaker: Frasier
text: Ah, then I suppose we can dispense with the breathing exercises I was going to recommend.  Please, if you would. [_indicating the choir's risers behind the orchestra_] Off you go.

speaker: Niles
text: Uh, Frasier... did you mean to cut paragraph five of my monologue?

speaker: Frasier
text: Gosh, I might have, Niles.  I've just been so busy.  What was the gist?

speaker: Niles
text: A lighthearted lampoon of mental health care abuse.

speaker: Frasier
text: Ah, yes, I did.  I was afraid that some fussbudget might take offense at my jape about lobotomies.

speaker: Niles
text: Well, I suppose it's best to play it safe, although I did Like the way you indicated manic depression with a slide whistle.

speaker: Niles
text: Do we really have to use so many musicians?

speaker: Frasier
text: For the sound I want, yes.

speaker: Niles
text: Whatever happened to the concept of "less is more"?

speaker: Frasier
text: Ah, but if less is more, just think of how much more "more" will be.

speaker: Frasier
text: You may be seated.

speaker: Frasier
text: Ladies and gentlemen, if I may have your attention, please, I'd like to take a few minutes to explain my artistic vision.

speaker: Timpanist
text: Take as long as you want, we're all on the clock.

speaker: Frasier
text: Point well taken, moving right along...

speaker: Roz
text: Frasier...I'm sorry we're late.  We got stuck in traffic. Some stupid bus broke down.  This is Leon.  _Leon looks like a starving folk-type musician, with long hair and a scruffy beard._

speaker: Frasier
text: Ah, hello, Leon.

speaker: Leon
text: Hey, Dr. Crane.

speaker: Frasier
text: [_shaking his hand_] Lovely to meet you.  Listen, why don't you help yourself to the refreshment table there.  I need to have a few words with Roz.

speaker: Frasier
text: Roz, we've got a problem!  In scoring this, I had to eliminate the guitar part.

speaker: Roz
text: Well, put it back.

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, I can't.  I'm afraid another instrument might make Things sound cluttered... unless, of course, Leon can play the bagpipe.

speaker: Roz
text: The bagpipe?

speaker: Frasier
text: Yes!  Our show deals with a whole range of human emotion from euphoria to despair, and nothing says despair so quickly as the skirl of a bagpipe.

speaker: Roz
text: Nothing says "Turn off the radio" so quickly either.  Isn't there something else he can play?

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, uh... yes, yes!  Actually, our triangle player called in with a touch of tinnitus.  Here we are.

speaker: Frasier
text: Leon, I have some good news for you.  I had to eliminate the Guitar part, but I'm promoting you to first triangle.

speaker: Leon
text: Uh, I've never played one of these.  It looks tricky.

speaker: Roz
text: I'll work with him.

speaker: Frasier
text: Yes, off you go.

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, then, now people, before we start, are there any questions?

speaker: Frasier
text: Yes, viola.

speaker: Tiffany
text: My name is Tiffany.

speaker: Frasier
text: No, no no.  I'm calling you by your instrument name, so as to avoid confusion.

speaker: Tiffany
text: Oh, well I have a question about measure 34...

speaker: Frasier
text: Ah... I thought you might.  Yes, you see, I've accelerated the tempo there in order to depict the yearning of the superego. Very perceptive of you to spot that.

speaker: Tiffany
text: No, I meant, are these eighth notes or what?

speaker: Frasier
text: [_miffed_] Yes... eighth notes.  Anyone else?

speaker: Frasier
text: Yes, timpani?

speaker: Tiffany
text: You just answered my question.

speaker: Frasier
text: Not Tiffany, timpani.

speaker: Timpanist
text: What are we rehearsing this for?  Are we going to record it?

speaker: Frasier
text: Yes, actually, we are waiting for the final go-ahead from my station manager, and then we will be recording it, yes. Anyone else?

speaker: Frasier
text: Yes... actor.

speaker: Niles
text: I'm just wondering how my monologue is going to be audible over all these instruments.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, that's a good point, Niles. [_beat_] You may be seated. [_after Niles sits_] It is imperative that everyone play [_pianissimo_] during the spoken portions - very, very softly.  That applies particularly to brass and timpani.

speaker: Tiffany
text: Why me?

speaker: Frasier
text: [_incredulous at her dimness_] To the drums, Tiffany.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, Dad, Daphne, I'm so glad you came!

speaker: Daphne
text: Oh, well, after all, it is the world premiere of your theme song.

speaker: Frasier
text: Now, I don't have to search you two for any hidden recording devices, do I?  The last thing I need is some bootleg CD's flooding the marketplace.

speaker: Martin
text: Boy, you really got everything here!

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, it's not a time for stinting, Dad.  I've got everything from the African rain stick to the Javanese tam-tam.

speaker: Martin
text: [_at the refreshment table_] Are the tam-tams the long ones with the cream in the middle?

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, Kenny, Kenny!  I'm so glad you made it.  Listen, I think you're in for a bit of a surprise.

speaker: Kenny
text: Well, I gotta tell you, I don't surprise easily. [_seeing the orchestra_] Whoa!

speaker: Frasier
text: Our little ensemble.  Heh-heh.

speaker: Kenny
text: So many musicians... all working on a weekend.

speaker: Frasier
text: Now, listen, I realize that we are a bit over budget, and I promise, I will pick up the difference myself.

speaker: Frasier
text: All right.  The time has come to unveil my magnum opus.  Just Let me do a little fine-tuning on the opening fanfare.

speaker: Frasier
text: Uh, brass, if you will please, in four, the first measure? _Frasier beats out a preparatory measure in 4/4.  The trumpets play a very conventional fanfare flawlessly._

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, you see, that's fine as far as it goes, but this time I want you to do it with a bit more... grandeur.  With some majesty and a soupcon of awe. _The trumpets play the fanfare exactly as before.  Frasier turns to Kenny, Martin, Daphne, and Roz, who are seated behind him._

speaker: Frasier
text: There, you see.  That's what good conducting can do.

speaker: Frasier
text: All right, everyone.  The time we have been waiting for is at hand.  And with a simple bow of thanks to the muse Calliope, let us begin.  And... _The four audience members exchange a look of incredulity, not knowing what to expect.  The maestro raises his baton, and we hear his magnum opus.  He conducts a preparatory measure again, and the trumpets play the fanfare.  This is followed by the strings, who settle into a conventional broadway-style vamp that doesn't seem to "fit" the preceding fanfare.  After a harp glissando, the first chorus is then presented by three soloists and the choir._  CHORUS 1

speaker: Soloist 1
text: (tenor)   _Who can you turn to for prompt diagnosis?_

speaker: Soloist 2
text: (soprano) _A fetish or fantasy_

speaker: Soloist 3
text: (bass)    _Sex or psychosis_

speaker: Soloist 1
text: _No problem at all, let us handle your call_

speaker: Choir
text: (unison)  _On our show!  On our show!_  _Prominent drum beats accompany "On our show!"  Martin exchanges a glance with Daphne and Roz._  CHORUS 2

speaker: Soloist 2
text: _Bring us your traumas, your latent neurosis_

speaker: Soloist 1
text: _Erectile disfunction (the "r" prominently rolled)_

speaker: Soloist 3
text: _Bed-wetting narcosis_

speaker: Soloist 1
text: _There's no need for shame, you can use a false name_

speaker: Choir
text: (unison) _On our show!  On our show!_ _Frasier is delighted with the performance thus far.  The orchestra now settles down to a suspenseful and quietly sustained chord.  The musical material of the choruses is very clich ed Broadway/Disney-style fare, so the suspenseful film-score background chords and the overly dramatic delivery of Niles's following monologue is extremely incongruous:_

speaker: Niles
text: [_rising_] Who dares enter the dark labyrinth of the human mind? _A percussion player draws a string bow across a metal object, producing an unpleasant whining sound.  The orchestra changes harmonies to a higher chord.  Frasier marks time with dramatic baton gestures as he prepares to cue the harmonic changes._

speaker: Niles
text: What festering secrets are buried in the recesses of the subconscious? _Another percussionist drags something across a gong, producing another unpleasant sound._

speaker: Niles
text: Lurid images! _Another harmonic shift upward comes with Niles's words, which are followed by the shaking of a circus-style rattle/whistle._

speaker: Niles
text: Lewd desires! _Yet another chord shift with Niles's line, followed by a slide whistle, which presumably illustrates the "lewd desires."_

speaker: Niles
text: Guilty pleasures! _A chord shift with Niles again, and a "grunting" sound from the orchestra._

speaker: Niles
text: Strange compulsions! _One more harmonic shift with Niles, followed by a dissonant trombone splat.  Niles, startled, stares at the trombone player.  The strings then play a quick rising transitional passage, leading to a suspenseful high note._

speaker: Niles
text: The whole catalogue of human behavior from the aberrant to the monstrous lurks behind a locked door to which one man holds the key! _A huge beat of the gong (tam-tam), which startles the others, Particularly Martin... and then a harp glissando leads us back seamlessly to the broadway-style chorus music.  Niles sits, grinning broadly._  CHORUS 3

speaker: Soloist 1
text: (tenor)  _So if you are stymied to find a prognosis_

speaker: Soloist 2
text: (soprano)_And ask yourself, just like Freud:_

speaker: Soloist 3
text: (bass)   _"Himmel, was los ist?"_

speaker: Soloist 1
text: _Stop scratching your head, let us cure it instead_

speaker: Choir
text: (unison) _On our show!  On our show!_ _The little instrumental riff before "On our show!" is different in the three choruses.  The following coda sounds as if it has been directly lifted from "Supercalifragilisticexpialidocious" from "Mary Poppins."_ CODA

speaker: Choir
text: (single note)_Now here is the man to explain The tortured terrain of your brain The man who feels everyone's pain... Dr. Crane!  Dr. Crane!  Frasier Crane!!_ _The choir finally harmonizes on the last "Crane."  Leon's triangle has been featured prominently in the last shouts of "Dr. Crane." The final chord is drawn out in another broadway clich e, and after the cutoff, Leon provides a final triangle beat.  Frasier lowers his baton, extremely proud of his opus. _ [_N.B. The piece can be heard on the "Frasier" soundtrack CD._]

speaker: Roz
text: [_the only person applauding_] Way to go, Leon! _Daphne begins to applaud with hesitation.  Martin is mystified. Kenny has an indescribable look of amazement and sits motionless._

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, Kenny.  What's your reaction? _Kenny's facial expression remains frozen and he is motionless. Finally:_

speaker: Kenny
text: [_hushed_] Wow.

speaker: Frasier
text: Takes your breath away, doesn't it?

speaker: Kenny
text: [_again_] Wow.

speaker: Frasier
text: I thought as much, and in anticipation of your approval, I had the forethought to order in a little bubbly.  Niles, if you would help me, please?

speaker: Frasier
text: [_to Niles_] Oh, you were wonderful!

speaker: Niles
text: Thank you, the trombone frightened me.

speaker: Kenny
text: [_again, the same_] Wow.

speaker: Martin
text: Well that was sure something, wasn't it?

speaker: Daphne
text: I'll say.  Sort of like Gilbert and Sullivan -- only frightening.

speaker: Kenny
text: A little jingle, that's all we wanted.  Yeah, ten seconds to start the show.

speaker: Roz
text: [_trying to mediate_] Well, maybe Frasier can cut this down...

speaker: Kenny
text: [_cutting her off_] He gives me harps and drums and... people speaking German.  All we wanted was a simple little jingle.

speaker: Daphne
text: Probably more like the one you came up with.  Tell him yours, Mr. Crane.

speaker: Martin
text: No, no, no, it was nothing.  I can't even remember how it goes.

speaker: Daphne
text: Well, I do. [_singing:_]

speaker: Martin
text: No, it doesn't go like that.

speaker: Kenny
text: Well, then you sing it, Mr. Crane.

speaker: Martin
text: Well, all right... but it's really nothing.

speaker: Martin
text: _What's new?  I'm listenin' Feelin' blue?  I'm listenin'..._ Feelin' sad, feelin' mad, feelin' bad, feelin' glad I'm listenin'!_

speaker: Kenny
text: That's exactly the kind of thing we're looking for!

speaker: Kenny
text: You know, it sets the mood, it - it says it all.  Did that just pop into your head?

speaker: Frasier
text: [_coming up behind him and handing him a glass_] Hardly.  It was gut-wrenching, but you know, it's nice to know that I made it look easy.

speaker: Kenny
text: No, no, no.  I'm talking about your dad's little jingle.

speaker: Frasier
text: [_taken aback_] Dad's?

speaker: Kenny
text: Yeah, he just sang it.  It's exactly the type of thing we need.  You know, simple, catchy...you know, we ought to just use that one.

speaker: Frasier
text: No, no, Kenny, no.  I mean, if simple is what you wanted, you should have just said so.

speaker: Kenny
text: I thought I did.

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, obviously not.  Now that I know what you want, well, there's nothing easier.  Of course I can write simple.  I promise you, it'll be something far more memorable than what my dad came up with.

speaker: Kenny
text: Well, I don't know, I remember it..._sings_  _Some of the choir members, including the soloists and director, take up the jingle._

speaker: Choir
text: _Feelin' blue?  I'm listenin'... Feelin' sad, feelin' mad, feelin' bad, feelin' glad I'm listenin'!_

speaker: Frasier
text: [_indignant and humiliated_] You're off the clock!  _He exits in a huff.  FADE TO:_  **IT'S WHY GERSHWIN'S TEETH WERE IMMACULATE**  _Scene 6 - Frasier's apartment He is seated at the piano playing some ornate classical-style improvisation.  He breaks it off and plunks out the last two lines of "Row, Row, Row Your Boat."  He places his head in his hand in frustration.  Martin enters in his robe._

speaker: Martin
text: Hey, Fras.  How's it goin'?

speaker: Frasier
text: "Merrily, merrily."

speaker: Martin
text: Well, you know, it's getting kind of late.  Maybe you should call it a night, huh?

speaker: Frasier
text: Dad, you heard Kenny.  I have to come up with something as simple as yours by Monday.  By the way, thanks once again for completely upstaging me today.

speaker: Martin
text: Oh, come on, I'm sorry I stole your thunder, but it's not like I did it on purpose.

speaker: Frasier
text: I know.  I know.  I'm sorry.  It's just... I don't know why I'm having such a hard time with this.

speaker: Martin
text: Well... maybe you're just thinking too much.  I mean, look at me.  I go to the bathroom, I'm flossing my teeth, and that song pops into my head.

speaker: Frasier
text: Are you suggesting that I bring out a spool of floss?

speaker: Martin
text: Well, it might not be a bad idea, for a couple of reasons.

speaker: Martin
text: Frasier, why don't you just decide what you want to say and Say it?  Not a lot of big words and showing off.  You know, and the tune should be something simple - something you can whistle.  I tried whistling that thing you wrote today, and I got lightheaded.  Of course, it might have been that last doughnut.  I went back for one of those African rainsticks. Ooh...

speaker: Frasier
text: The truth is, Dad, I've... I'm not sure I can do simple.

speaker: Martin
text: Well, I don't know if you can't or if you just don't want to. And you know, some of the best things in the world are simple, Fras.  Just like that art gallery you took me to a couple of months ago.  Do you remember?  You were oohing and ahhing at this painting of a big red dot.

speaker: Frasier
text: Yeah, Dad, but there is a difference between simple and deceptively simple.

speaker: Martin
text: Well, all I'm saying is that it's fine to be smart, but you shouldn't have to be proving it all the time, that's all.  You know, just as an experiment, tell me what it is you're trying to say stripped down to nuts and bolts.

speaker: Frasier
text: All right, um... in my first stanza, I want to represent myself as the... ombudsman between the conscious and subconscious minds of my listeners.

speaker: Martin
text: Ah.  Well, there you are, that's the song right there.  All we need is a rhyme for "ombudsman" and we can go to bed.

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, I was playing around with "north woodsman."

speaker: Martin
text: Oh, Frasier.  Look, I'm going to tell you what your show's about: People have a problem, they're feeling low, they call you, you make them feel better.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, for God's sake, Dad.

speaker: Martin
text: Well, that's it!  That's it.  Why don't you just write about that?

speaker: Frasier
text: How would that sound exactly? [_He recites:_] _If you've got a problem If you're feelin' low Lookin' for some answers..._ Oh, gosh, now I'm stuck.  How will I ever find a rhyme for "low"?

speaker: Martin
text: Okay, smart-aleck.  I was just trying to help.

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, thanks, Dad.  I'm sorry, you know, it's just not my thing.

speaker: Martin
text: Okay, well, I'm going to bed.  So, if you need any help tomorrow, all you got to do is ask.

speaker: Frasier
text: Thanks, Dad. _Martin exits toward his bedroom.  Frasier returns to the piano, waits until he is gone, and sits.  He begins to plunk out a catchy melody and sings to it:_

speaker: Frasier
text: _If you've got a problem... If you're feelin' low Lookin' for some answers..._

speaker: Martin
text: [_completing the verse rhyme and tune from offstage:_]  _Frasier looks up, mildly indignant.  FADE immediately to...  Scene 7 - KACL We hear a catchy introduction, and then then Frasier's tune, sung in Andrews Sisters-style harmony by a group of female vocalists. Kenny, Roz, and Frasier are leaning over the desk listening to the recorded song._

speaker: Vocalists
text: _If you've got a problem If you're feelin' low Lookin' for some answers Things you need to know, All you've got to do is ask (tempo slows) All you've got to do is ask._  _A triangle dings to end the song.  Frasier, Kenny, and Roz have been bouncing to the catchy jingle, and Frasier is proud of it, simple as it is.  FADE OUT  END OF ACT II_
